data.title: GeneDx drops after short report from Grizzly Research
data.description:
• GeneDX (NASDAQ:WGS) pared an earlier decline and is now down 3.4% after a short report from Grizzly Research on the genetic testing company.
  • Grizzly Research disclosed that it's short shares of GeneDX (NASDAQ:WGS).
  • GeneDX didn't immediately respond to Seeking Alpha's email request for comment.
  • GeneDX (WGS) has short interest of 7.8%.

data.title: Equinor targets $23B free cash flow through 2027 with 10% oil and gas production growth
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Equinor ASA (NYSE:EQNR) Q4 2024

Management View

  • CEO Anders Opedal announced plans to deliver more than 10% growth in oil and gas production from 2024 to 2027, supported by portfolio optimization and high-value transactions. He stated that Equinor expects to generate $23 billion in free cash flow over the next three years, with a total capital distribution of $9 billion for 2025.
  • The company anticipates an increase in production to 2.2 million barrels per day by 2030, up from 2 million barrels in last year’s outlook.
  • CFO Torgrim Reitan highlighted Equinor's capacity to reduce organic CapEx to $13 billion annually for 2025–2026 and the company’s resilience at lower price environments, with a cash-neutral price of $50 per barrel.

Outlook

  • Management projected a return on capital employed of approximately 15% through 2030, expecting free cash flow growth of over 50% from 2024 to 2027.
  • Capital allocation priorities remain focused on a predictable and growing cash dividend and competitive share buybacks, with the 2025 distribution consisting of $4 billion in cash dividends and $5 billion in share buybacks.
  • The company retired its gross CapEx ambition, signaling a shift toward prioritizing value-driven investments, particularly in renewables and low-carbon solutions.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted operating income for Q4 was $7.9 billion, driven by strong operational performance, particularly from the Norwegian continental shelf. Cash flow from operations reached $18 billion for 2024, exceeding earlier guidance.
  • International upstream operations achieved significant improvements, with free cash flow expected to grow from $1.3 billion in 2024 to more than $5 billion by 2030.
  • Equinor’s net debt ratio stood at 11.9%, with plans for further reductions in Q1 2025.

Q&A

  • Martijn Rats, Morgan Stanley: Asked about the shift in Equinor’s renewable and low-carbon strategy. CFO Reitan explained that the company has phased out projects lacking profitability and high-graded its portfolio for stronger returns. He also reiterated a focus on flexibility to adapt to market challenges.
  • Biraj Borkhataria, RBC: Inquired about the decision to continue with the Empire Wind and Rosebank projects despite policy risks. CEO Opedal emphasized robust project economics and long-term strategic importance.
  • Teodor Sveen Nilsen, SpareBank 1 Markets: Questioned guidance on organic production growth. Opedal outlined contributions from new international projects, as well as sustained production from the Norwegian continental shelf.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed concerns about risks associated with renewables and offshore wind investments, though sentiment was tempered by confidence in Equinor’s operational execution.
  • Management maintained a cautiously optimistic tone, emphasizing resilience and a disciplined approach to capital allocation. Prepared remarks conveyed confidence, while responses to analyst inquiries balanced clarity with acknowledgment of uncertainties.
  • Compared to Q3 2024, management showed stronger conviction in its ability to achieve production and cash flow targets, but faced persistent skepticism from analysts regarding renewable investments.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Management tone in Q4 reflected increased confidence in delivering free cash flow and production growth targets compared to Q3.
  • Renewables strategy showed a marked shift, with reduced CapEx and a focus on optimizing existing projects, in contrast to the broader ambitions discussed in Q3.
  • Analysts’ focus evolved from questions about Ørsted investments in Q3 to concerns about project risks and execution timelines in Q4.
  • Financial performance metrics, such as cash flow and production, showed substantial growth over the prior quarter.

Risks and Concerns

  • Analysts raised concerns about geopolitical risks, particularly policy changes affecting the Empire Wind and Rosebank projects.
  • Management highlighted mitigation strategies, including robust project economics, diversified portfolios, and maintaining a strong balance sheet.
  • Risks in offshore wind and renewables were addressed through a revised approach emphasizing value-driven investments and lower CapEx.

Final Takeaway

Equinor outlined a robust strategy for increasing production and free cash flow while adapting its renewables and low-carbon ambitions to prioritize profitability. The company’s focus on operational excellence and disciplined capital allocation positions it well to deliver strong shareholder returns, despite uncertainties in global energy markets and renewables.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Uber sees 17%-21% gross bookings growth in Q1 2025 with strong mobility and delivery momentum
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Uber Technologies, Inc. (NYSE:UBER) Q4 2024

Management View

  • Dara Khosrowshahi highlighted acceleration across audience, trips, and top-line growth. Gross bookings growth exceeded expectations, with a 21% year-over-year increase in constant currency for Q4 2024. The Uber One membership program grew by 5 million members during the quarter, reaching a total of 30 million, a 60% increase year-over-year.

  • Khosrowshahi emphasized Uber's success in exceeding its commitments for 2024, surpassing goals across gross bookings, adjusted EBITDA, and free cash flow conversion. He stated that Uber started 2025 with significant momentum despite foreign exchange headwinds.

  • Prashanth Mahendra-Rajah disclosed that Q4 2024 EBITDA margins reached 7.8% of gross bookings, increasing 30 basis points year-over-year, supported by supply incentives and operational leverage despite higher insurance costs. He also noted strong membership growth and product expansion, such as Uber Teens, which more than doubled the number of countries it serves.

  • On autonomous vehicles, Khosrowshahi discussed advancements, noting a focus on partnerships like Waymo. He said commercialization will take longer but stressed Uber’s role as an indispensable partner for AV players. The Austin rollout with Waymo is set to launch in March 2025.

Outlook

  • Khosrowshahi projected Q1 2025 gross bookings growth of 17%-21% in constant currency, with continued profit expansion. He reiterated confidence in Uber's ability to deliver on its three-year growth framework, balancing top-line and bottom-line growth.

  • Mahendra-Rajah highlighted FX headwinds expected to impact Q1 2025 revenue by 5.5 percentage points, compared to 3 points in Q4 2024. He emphasized that audience growth would continue to drive performance, similar to Q4 2024.

  • Management indicated that foreign exchange effects would primarily impact revenue but not EBITDA margins, showcasing Uber’s ability to absorb these fluctuations effectively.

Financial Results

  • Uber reported 21% year-over-year gross bookings growth in Q4 2024, marking the fourth quarter in five with at least 20% growth. Adjusted EBITDA grew 60% year-over-year.

  • Delivery saw gross bookings accelerate sequentially, driven by increased membership and expanded selection. Uber Eats added 1 million active merchants, a 16% increase year-over-year.

  • Membership growth played a key role, with Uber One members spending three times more than non-members. Memberships reached 30 million, up 60% year-over-year.

Q&A

  • Brian Nowak, Morgan Stanley, asked about investments in autonomous fleets and profitability trends. Khosrowshahi stated Uber is aggressively investing in AV fleet supply and technical partnerships while maintaining its three-year outlook. Mahendra-Rajah noted Mobility EBITDA margins grew to 7.8% of gross bookings in Q4, supported by supply incentives and operating leverage.

  • Eric Sheridan, Goldman Sachs, inquired about scaling in less dense geographies. Mahendra-Rajah explained that these areas are growing 1.5 times faster than dense urban centers through tailored supply and demand incentives. Khosrowshahi added that product enhancements, such as Reserve, are enhancing service quality in these regions.

  • Justin Post, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, questioned Q1 2025 guidance. Mahendra-Rajah clarified that headwinds from leap-year comparisons, weather, and FX were factored into the 17%-21% gross bookings growth guidance.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts raised concerns about FX headwinds, insurance costs, and the pace of AV commercialization. The tone was neutral to slightly negative, particularly regarding the challenges of achieving high utilization for AV fleets.

  • Management maintained a confident tone during prepared remarks, emphasizing strong performance and growth opportunities. Khosrowshahi expressed optimism about AV partnerships and noted Uber's ability to balance aggressive investments with profitability targets.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, management appeared more confident in addressing insurance cost moderation and leveraging FX-neutral strategies to sustain growth.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Gross bookings growth accelerated to 21% in Q4 2024, compared to 20% in Q3. Membership growth also picked up, with Uber One members increasing by 5 million in Q4 compared to 25 million total in Q3.

  • Management's tone remained consistent, highlighting strategic priorities such as AV investments and expanding supply in less dense areas. Analysts’ focus shifted slightly toward the impact of FX and insurance costs on profitability.

  • Strategic initiatives, such as Uber Teens and grocery partnerships, continued to expand, aligning with the broader goal of penetrating less dense geographies.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management acknowledged the challenges of FX headwinds, which are expected to weigh more heavily on Q1 2025 results. Insurance costs remain a concern, although Mahendra-Rajah noted signs of moderation.

  • Khosrowshahi highlighted the long timeline for AV commercialization, emphasizing that significant regulatory, operational, and cost hurdles remain.

  • Analysts questioned the sustainability of profitability growth amid rising costs and FX pressures.

Final Takeaway

Uber’s Q4 2024 results showcased strong growth across gross bookings, EBITDA, and membership. The company exceeded its annual commitments while investing in strategic initiatives like AV partnerships and geographic expansion. Management projected solid Q1 2025 growth despite FX headwinds, signaling confidence in its three-year framework. Investors should monitor developments in AV commercialization, insurance costs, and the impact of FX on revenue growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Harley-Davidson Q4 sales crater on high financing costs
data.description:
As cyclical headwinds for discretionary products continued and increased financing costs drove sales down 47%, Harley-Davidson swung to a loss in the fourth quarter, missing expectations by a significant margin and driving shares lower at Wednesday’s open.

“In 2024 we saw our performance being significantly impacted by the high-interest rates that negatively impacted consumer confidence,” said CEO Jochen Zeitz, attributing soft demand on

Consolidated results for the manufacturing and financing arms of the business saw a 35% drop in revenue to $688M, $217M less than Wall Street expected, while net income deteriorated by 550% to a loss of $117M, or $0.93 per share, well below expectations for a loss of $0.66 per share.

In the company’s motorcycle division, motorcycle sales fell 60%, parts & accessories sales were down 10%, and apparel sales dropped 6%. With an overall operating loss of $214M, the division’s gross margin evaporated to negative 0.8% from 22.9% a year ago.

Sales were again softest in Asia Pacific (-26%), following by a 13% drop in sales in North America, and 7% fewer sales in Europe and in Latin America.

Revenue in Harley-Davidson Financial Services improved by 4% on higher interest rates, while operating income fell 20% due to higher borrowing costs and a higher expectation for loan defaults.

Finally, the company saw 54% few sales of its electric motorcycles, driving revenue for the segment down 35%.

Looking ahead for 2025, revenue in the motorcycle segment is expected to be flat to down 5% and operating income margin of 7% to 8%, while operating income in its financing division is expected to be down 10% to 15%. The company also expects to sell 1,000 to 1,500 electric motorcycles, up from 612 units in 2024.

For the combined company, earnings are anticipated to be flat to down 5%, with capital investments totaling $225M to $250M for the year.

Shares opened 5% lower, leaving the stock at a 4-year low of $25.60.

data.title: Zurn Elkay targets $405M-$420M EBITDA in 2025 with margin expansion focus
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Zurn Elkay Water Solutions Corporation (NYSE:ZWS) Q4 2024

Management View

  • CEO Todd Adams highlighted 4% core growth in Q4 2024, leading to an 8% adjusted EBITDA increase and a 100 basis point expansion in margins to 24.6%. For the full year, EBITDA grew 15% to $390 million, with margins rising 270 basis points to 24.9%. Free cash flow for the quarter was $55 million, totaling $272 million for 2024.
  • Adams noted the company repurchased $20 million in shares during the quarter, contributing to a full-year total of $150 million at an average price below $32. The company also allocated $20 million to top off its pension plan, with plans to exit it by the end of 2025.
  • CFO David Pauli reported Q4 sales of $371 million, reflecting 4% year-over-year growth. Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter reached $91 million, with strong margin expansion driven by productivity initiatives and Elkay-related synergies. Net debt leverage ended the year at a low 0.8x, enabling significant capital allocation flexibility.

Outlook

  • Management expects 2025 core sales growth similar to 2024, adjusted EBITDA in the range of $405 million to $420 million, and free cash flow of approximately $290 million.
  • For Q1 2025, the company projects low single-digit core sales growth and adjusted EBITDA margins of 24.5% to 25%.
  • Pauli emphasized proactive monitoring of tariff uncertainties, noting the company has reduced its exposure to materials from China to less than 10% by the end of 2026. Given the evolving tariff environment, management stated readiness to implement price increases as needed.

Financial Results

  • Q4 adjusted EBITDA reached $91 million, with a 100 basis point margin expansion compared to the prior year. Full-year adjusted EBITDA stood at $390 million, with margins improving by 270 basis points to 24.9%.
  • Free cash flow for 2024 totaled $272 million, exceeding prior guidance, while $150 million was deployed for share repurchases.
  • The company achieved 4% year-over-year core sales growth in Q4, driven by strength in non-residential end markets, partially offset by softness in residential and parts of the commercial segment.

Q&A

  • Bryan Blair, Oppenheimer: Asked about first and second-half dynamics across end markets. CEO Todd Adams responded that institutional markets, particularly healthcare and education, could see accelerated growth in the second half of 2025, supported by Dodge Starts data.
  • Adam Farley, Stifel: Inquired about tariff impact expectations. CFO David Pauli stated tariffs were not included in the guidance but emphasized the company's flexibility to navigate any tariff changes through price adjustments and supply chain strategies.
  • Jeffrey Hammond, KeyBanc: Asked about the company's exposure to Dodge Starts data. Adams clarified that institutional growth projections align with Dodge Starts, with significant benefits expected in 2026 as starts materialize.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed cautious optimism, particularly regarding institutional growth potential and M&A opportunities in 2025. Questions about tariffs and macroeconomic impacts reflected slight concerns about external uncertainties.
  • Management maintained a confident and proactive tone, emphasizing operational efficiencies, strong capital allocation flexibility, and strategic focus areas. CEO Todd Adams frequently highlighted the company's ability to adapt to challenges.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analysts' tone remained consistent but focused more on potential tariff impacts and their implications. Management maintained a similar level of confidence, with no significant changes in tone or sentiment.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Both quarters reported 4% core growth, but Q4 saw stronger focus on free cash flow performance, with $272 million for the full year, compared to Q3's $87 million in the quarter.
  • Adjusted EBITDA margins in Q4 were slightly lower at 24.6% versus 25.6% in Q3. However, the full-year margin expansion of 270 basis points exceeded the 250-270 basis point guidance provided in Q3.
  • Management's tone remained consistent, with continued emphasis on productivity, margin expansion, and capital allocation flexibility.

Risks and Concerns

  • Potential tariff impacts remain a key uncertainty for 2025. Management noted their preparedness to implement price increases and adjust supply chain strategies as needed.
  • Elevated interest rates were raised as a potential medium-to-long-term risk. Management stated that most of their business is insulated from interest rate sensitivity but acknowledged the broader macroeconomic impacts.
  • Analysts also questioned potential delays or hesitancy in project starts, though management reported no significant pushouts.

Final Takeaway

Zurn Elkay reported solid Q4 results, with 4% core growth and continued margin expansion driven by productivity initiatives. For 2025, the company projects adjusted EBITDA between $405 million and $420 million, with plans to navigate potential tariff impacts through flexible supply chain strategies. Analysts expressed cautious optimism, particularly regarding institutional growth and M&A opportunities, while management maintained a confident tone, emphasizing operational efficiencies and financial stability.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Juniper returns to growth in Q4, for 2025 investor focus remains on HPE deal: analysts
data.description:
Piper Sandler said Juniper Networks' (NYSE:JNPR) stock will likely continue trading at a discount due to the U.S. Department of Justice's concerns over the potential acquisition by Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), but fundamentals are showing an improvement.

The firm maintained its Neutral outlook on Juniper and $40 price target. On Tuesday, Juniper reported its fourth quarter results, which beat estimates, and the company and Hewlett Packard will defend the transaction and remain fully committed to completing it. The remarks came on the heels of the DOJ's announcing last week that it has sued to block Hewlett Packard's potential $14B acquisition of the rival wireless networking technology provider, Juniper, on competition concerns.

Analysts led by James Fish said Juniper reported slight top-line upside that their checks suggested, which was complemented with the largest operational upside over the last nearly five years.

The analysts added that Juniper faced easy comps (with first half 2025 facing even easier compares), but the underlying metrics indicate some year-end budget flush, datacenter refresh picking up, Cloud and AI demand, and Mist demand holding strong, all of which echo signals from other vendors and is another good sign for networking names yet to report.

Fish and his team noted that they were most impressed that the backlog grew 30% year-over-year and seemingly was built throughout the course of the year, suggesting further strengthahead (particularly with Cloud customers).

UBS also kept its Neutral rating on Juniper with a $40 price target on the stock.

Analyst David Vogt and his team said Juniper returned to growth in the fourth quarter after five quarters of decline, with revenue up 3% year-over-year on strong cloud results. Cloud has been the driver of revenue growth in recent quarters and continued in the fourth quarter, up 16% year-over-year.

The analysts added that Juniper enters 2025 with improving momentum in the business, but investor focus remains on the close of the acquisition by Hewlett Packard, which remains pending following the DOJ complaint.

data.title: Kroger, Cigna's Express Scripts sign customer access deal
data.description:
Cigna's (NYSE:CI) Express Scripts has signed an agreement with Kroger's (NYSE:KR) healthcare division that gives Express Scripts customers access to prescription medications and healthcare services through the Kroger Family of Pharmacies.

Under the deal, Kroger pharmacies will immediately resume service for customers participating in Express Scripts' Medicare Part D plans and Tricare/Department of Defense plans. Express Scripts commercial and Medicaid plan customers will also be able to add the Kroger Family of Pharmacies to their respective networks, according to a statement.

Kroger noted that the Express Scripts plans cover more than 100M people in the United States.

data.title: Global Technologies reports 29% growth in shareholder equity over first half of fiscal year
data.description:
• Global Technologies (OTCPK:GTLL) announced a 29% increase in shareholder equity over the first six months of its fiscal year.

  • Source: Press Release
